# Chord: Minor Major 7th in G# (Shape: C)

## Brief Presentation
The Minor Major 7th chord in G# (Shape: C) consists of the notes G#, B, D#, and F#. This chord has a unique and sophisticated sound due to the combination of a minor triad with a major 7th interval. In the key of G#, the chord is formed by playing the notes G# (root), B (minor 3rd), D# (perfect 5th), and F# (major 7th). This chord has a melancholic yet jazzy feel when played in various musical contexts.

## Notes and Intervals
- Root: G#
- Minor 3rd: B
- Perfect 5th: D#
- Major 7th: F#

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The Minor Major 7th chord in G# is commonly used in jazz, soul, and R&B music. It adds a touch of sophistication and tension to compositions, creating a rich and complex harmonic texture. This chord is often used in ballads, jazz standards, and neo-soul songs to evoke feelings of introspection and emotional depth.

## Songs
Here are three songs that feature the Minor Major 7th chord in G#:
1. "Misty" by Erroll Garner - This classic jazz standard prominently features the Minor Major 7th chord, adding a dreamy and nostalgic quality to the melody.
2. "The Nearness of You" by Norah Jones - In this soulful ballad, the Minor Major 7th chord in G# is used to create a romantic and intimate atmosphere.
3. "Isn't She Lovely" by Stevie Wonder - This R&B hit incorporates the Minor Major 7th chord to infuse the song with a sense of longing and sweetness.
